event.doc_name: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief
Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief
Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: Plaintiffs are immigrant youth under the age of 21 who have applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile Status (SIJS), a form of humanitarian relief that provides vulnerable youth with a path to long-term legal status.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs are immigrant youth under the age of 21 who have applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile Status (SIJS).

evidence.text: Leobardo Moreno Galvez ... is a 20-year-old citizen of Mexico. ... Jose Luis Vicente Ramos ... is a 20-year-old citizen of Guatemala. ... Angel de Jesus Muñoz Olivera ... is a 19-year-old citizen of Mexico.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs are citizens of Mexico (Leobardo Moreno Galvez and Angel de Jesus Muñoz Olivera) and Guatemala (Jose Luis Vicente Ramos).

evidence.text: In October 2016, the Skagit County Superior Court placed him in the custody of a state agency or department and entered a SIJS order.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Leobardo Moreno Galvez was placed in the custody of a state agency by Skagit County Superior Court in December 2016 and entered a SIJS order.

evidence.text: On December 2, 2016, Leobardo submitted his SIJS petition to USCIS.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Leobardo submitted his SIJS petition to USCIS on December 2, 2016.

evidence.text: On December 20, 2018, USCIS denied his application solely based on its erroneous policy requiring predicate SIJS orders to be issued by a state court that has authority to make a legal conclusion about returning the youth to his parent’s custody.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: USCIS denied Leobardo’s SIJS petition on December 20, 2018.

evidence.text: In June 2018, the Pierce County Superior Court appointed Jose’s relative as his guardian in a Vulnerable Youth Guardianship proceeding, during which the court also entered a SIJS order.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Jose Luis Vicente Ramos was appointed a guardian by Pierce County Superior Court in June 2018 and entered a SIJS order.

evidence.text: On February 5, 2019, USCIS denied his application solely based on its erroneous policy requiring predicate SIJS orders to be issued by a state court that has authority to make a legal conclusion about returning the youth to his parent’s custody.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Jose submitted his SIJS petition to USCIS on February 5, 2019.

evidence.text: On February 5, 2019, USCIS denied his application solely based on its erroneous policy requiring predicate SIJS orders to be issued by a state court that has authority to make a legal conclusion about returning the youth to his parent’s custody.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: USCIS denied Jose’s SIJS petition on February 5, 2019.

evidence.text: In November 2017, the Pierce County Superior Court appointed Angel’s relative as his guardian in a Vulnerable Youth Guardianship proceeding, during which the court also entered a SIJS order.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Angel de Jesus Muñoz Olivera was appointed a guardian by Pierce County Superior Court in November 2017 and entered a SIJS order.

evidence.text: On November 15, 2017, Angel submitted his SIJS petition to USCIS.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Angel submitted his SIJS petition to USCIS on November 15, 2017.

evidence.text: USCIS has not adjudicated Angel’s SIJS petition. USCIS has not adjudicated Angel’s SIJS petition, which has been pending before USCIS for nearly 16 months.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Angel’s SIJS petition has remained pending for nearly 16 months.

evidence.text: USCIS’s 2018 policy requires predicate SIJS orders to be issued by a state court that has authority to make a legal conclusion about returning the youth to his parent’s custody.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: USCIS’s 2018 policy requires predicate SIJS orders to be issued by a state court that has authority to make a legal conclusion about returning the youth to their parent’s custody.

evidence.text: The government’s blanket denial of SIJS for youth who obtain predicate SIJS orders after turning 18 but before the age of 21 violates the controlling statute and the Administrative Procedure Act.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: USCIS’s blanket denial of SIJS for youth who obtain predicate SIJS orders after turning 18 but before the age of 21 violates the controlling statute and the Administrative Procedure Act.

evidence.text: Scores of other youth in Washington State face the same threat.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: The policy has caused denial or delay of SIJS petitions for the plaintiffs and other youth in Washington State.

evidence.text: The statutory framework requires USCIS to adjudicate SIJS petitions within 180 days of filing.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: The statutory framework requires USCIS to adjudicate SIJS petitions within 180 days of filing.

evidence.text: USCIS has not adjudicated Angel’s SIJS petition, which has been pending before USCIS for nearly 16 months.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: USCIS has not adjudicated Angel’s petition after nearly 16 months, violating the 180‑day deadline.

evidence.text: In February 2018, USCIS began imposing a new, ultra vires requirement outside the scope of the SIJS statute—that the state court issuing the predicate SIJS order have jurisdiction to return children to their parents’ custody.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: In February 2018, USCIS began imposing a new, ultra vires requirement outside the scope of the SIJS statute that the state court issuing the predicate SIJS order have jurisdiction to return children to their parents’ custody.

evidence.text: The case arises under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), 8 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., the regulations implementing the INA, and the APA, 5 U.S.C. § 701 et. seq.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: The case arises under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), 8 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., the regulations implementing the INA, and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 701 et. seq.

evidence.text: Jurisdiction is conferred on this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1331, as a civil action arising under the laws of the United States, and the Mandamus and Venue Act of 1962, 28 U.S.C. § 1361.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Jurisdiction is conferred on this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1331, as a civil action arising under the laws of the United States, and the Mandamus and Venue Act of 1962, 28 U.S.C. § 1361.

evidence.text: The United States has waived its sovereign immunity pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 702.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: The United States has waived its sovereign immunity pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 702.

evidence.text: The SIJS statute defines a child as an unmarried person under the age of 21.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: The SIJS statute defines a child as an unmarried person under the age of 21.

evidence.text: In 1990, Congress created Special Immigrant Juvenile Status to protect abused, abandoned, and neglected immigrant children in foster care and to provide them a pathway to lawful permanent residence.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: In 1990, Congress created Special Immigrant Juvenile Status to protect abused, abandoned, and neglected immigrant children in foster care and to provide them a pathway to lawful permanent residence.

evidence.text: Congress expanded SIJS eligibility through the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA), Pub. L. No. 110-457 § 235, 122 Stat. 5044 (2008), which was passed with broad bipartisan support.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Congress expanded SIJS eligibility through the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA), Pub. L. No. 110-457 § 235, 122 Stat. 5044 (2008), which was passed with broad bipartisan support.
